instruction: How were machine learning algorithms utilized in this research to estimate the microbiological quality on the surface of chicken breast fillets?
Output:
In this research, machine learning algorithms were utilized to estimate the microbiological quality on the surface of chicken breast fillets. Two software platforms, one commercial and one publicly available developed platform, were used for multivariate data analysis. These platforms comprised several machine learning algorithms. 

For the estimation of Total Viable Counts (TVC) and Pseudomonas spp. population on the surface of the samples, Partial Least Squares-Regression (PLS-R) models were developed using the commercial software. These models utilized Fourier transforms infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and multispectral image analysis (MSI) spectral data collected at different time intervals during storage. The performance of the PLS-R models was evaluated using root mean square error (RMSE) values.

In addition to the commercial software, an in-house sorfML platform was implemented. instruction: Can Fourier transforms infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and multispectral image analysis (MSI) be considered superior spectroscopic methods compared to traditional methods for assessing spoilage on the surface of chicken breast fillets?
Output: Yes, Fourier transforms infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and multispectral image analysis (MSI) can be considered superior spectroscopic methods compared to traditional methods for assessing spoilage on the surface of chicken breast fillets. The research mentioned in the past study evaluated the performance of FT-IR and MSI in tandem with multivariate data analysis and machine learning for the assessment of spoilage on chicken breast fillets. The results showed that both FT-IR and MSI, when combined with appropriate data analysis techniques, were able to accurately predict the microbiological quality of the chicken breast fillets. In terms of prediction accuracy, FT-IR analysis performed better than MSI, as indicated by lower root mean square error (RMSE) values for both Total Viable Counts (TVC) and Pseudomonas spp. population. Therefore, FT-IR can be considered a more efficient spectroscopic method for assessing spoilage on the surface of chicken breast fillets compared to MSI.
